thread.title: Whippet, L-Cat doubles teams come up short
thread.title_full: Whippet, L-Cat doubles teams come up short

author: Jacob Onak | Union sports writer
title: Whippet, L-Cat doubles teams come up short
text:
Whippet, L-Cat doubles teams come up short Jacob Onak | Union sports writer Daily Jefferson County Union 
MADISON — In a turn of good luck, the Whitewater High School girls’ tennis pairing of Alli Sedmak and Sally Hixson had a chance to defeat the very team that denied their first chance of getting to state. 
In a turn of bad luck, that same team continued playing a very high quality brand of tennis. 
Sedmak and Hixson fell 6-1, 6-1 to Shorewood’s Elizabeth Krioutchenkov and Hannah Rosenbaum in the first game of the WIAA Division 2 State Tennis Tournament at Nielsen Tennis Stadium on Thursday. 
It was Whitewater who actually won the first game of the set, but then Shorewood got on the serve, and Krioutchenkov — who was ranked fifth in the state in singles last season — started to dominate. 
The junior used her tall frame to generate a lot of power, and was firing on all cylinders. 
“(Krioutchenkov) was on a mission,” said Whitewater head coach Tim Nelson. “To be fair, we aren’t playing our badly... she can just cover the whole court.” 
Unfortunately the Whippets couldn’t capitalize on some breaks, making a couple of untimely mistakes and ultimately falling 6-1 in the first set. 
The second set started off how the first ended, with Shorewood taking its first two points. 
Whitewater was able to pull on back with some good serving by Hixson, but the Whippets couldn’t put together a come back, falling 6-1 in the second set to end its tournament run early. 
The seniors finished an impressive season together with a 23-3 overall record. 
RILEY-OEMIG 
An hour later, and on the complete opposite side of Nielsen Stadium, Lake Mills senior pairing of Caity Riley and Libby Oemig struggled to handle their nerves in their first match against Ashland’s Alison Tollas and Madison Yachinich. 
The duo, who hadn’t played a lot of tennis together this season because of team needs, fell 6-0, 6-2 in its first game of the State tournament. 
The nerves seemed to be pretty clear in the first set for Riley and Oemig. The two struggled to get a rhythm going and looked very timid playing, not taking advantage of some shots. Yachinich and Tollas continued to play solid tennis in order to win the first set. 
“We tried to work on the pressure situations and the nerves at state and we came here and hit earlier in the week and they were already nervous,” said Lake Mills’ head coach Cam Dary. “You could see that was the deciding factor in their matches.” 
After falling 6-0 in the first set, and being down 2-1 in the second, Riley got on the serve and started to play the tennis that Dary had expected. The senior hit some hard and accurate serves to put Tollas and Yachinich on their heels. 
“We went out and told them later on that it’s just time to let it all go and play with some reckless abandon and leave everything on the court and she did,” Dary said. “She just started being aggressive and it really worked and it got them some points, but they dug themselves in a hole and its tough to come back at this point in the season.” 
Unfortunately for Riley and Oemig, that was the only success the duo had in the match, eventually falling 6-0, 6-2. 
The two finish their   doubles record of 3-4.
